headline: 2 Cash-Heavy Stocks to Research Further and 1 We Turn Down
summary: A cash-heavy balance sheet is often a sign of strength, but not always. Some companies avoid debt because they have weak business models, limited expansion opportunities, or inconsistent cash flow.

headline: Carmakers accused of cheating emissions tests in UK lawsuits
summary: STORY: Lawyers accused some of the world's biggest carmakers of manipulating diesel emissions tests.The claims were made at London's High Court Monday by the legal representatives of 1.6 million claimants at the start of a huge trial.Owners of diesel vehicles made by certain brands between 2012 and 2017 allege the companies cheated emissions tests and are suing.The accused include Mercedes-Benz, Ford, Nissan, Renault, and Stellantis-owned Peugeot and Citroen.The manufacturers are accused of using unlawful "defeat devices" which detected when vehicles were being tested.The devices allegedly ensured nitrogen oxide emissions were kept within legal limits under test conditions.The claimants' lawyers argue the emissions were far higher when the cars were on the road, and in some cases up to 12 times test limits.They said this caused harm to the environment and entitled consumers to compensation.But the carmakers have called the claims fundamentally flawed.They argue there are justified reasons why systems to control emissions are calibrated to work differently in certain conditions.They also reject any similarity with 2015's 'Dieselgate' scandal, when Volkswagen admitted using defeat devices.It cost the German auto giant billions of dollars.The trial is due to conclude next year.

raw.headline: Carmakers accused of cheating emissions tests in UK lawsuits
raw.summary: STORY: Lawyers accused some of the world's biggest carmakers of manipulating diesel emissions tests.The claims were made at London's High Court Monday by the legal representatives of 1.6 million claimants at the start of a huge trial.Owners of diesel vehicles made by certain brands between 2012 and 2017 allege the companies cheated emissions tests and are suing.The accused include Mercedes-Benz, Ford, Nissan, Renault, and Stellantis-owned Peugeot and Citroen.The manufacturers are accused of using unlawful "defeat devices" which detected when vehicles were being tested.The devices allegedly ensured nitrogen oxide emissions were kept within legal limits under test conditions.The claimants' lawyers argue the emissions were far higher when the cars were on the road, and in some cases up to 12 times test limits.They said this caused harm to the environment and entitled consumers to compensation.But the carmakers have called the claims fundamentally flawed.They argue there are justified reasons why systems to control emissions are calibrated to work differently in certain conditions.They also reject any similarity with 2015's 'Dieselgate' scandal, when Volkswagen admitted using defeat devices.It cost the German auto giant billions of dollars.The trial is due to conclude next year.

headline: EV makers fill tax-credit void with costly discounts
summary: Many automakers are digging into their own coffers for big discounts to keep EV inventory moving, and several brands have introduced models with prices more comparable to gasoline vehicles.

headline: 2 Cash-Heavy Stocks with Solid Fundamentals and 1 We Brush Off
summary: Companies with more cash than debt can be financially resilient, but that doesn’t mean they’re all strong investments. Some lack leverage because they struggle to grow or generate consistent profits, making them unattractive borrowers.

raw.headline: 2 Cash-Heavy Stocks with Solid Fundamentals and 1 We Brush Off
raw.summary: Companies with more cash than debt can be financially resilient, but that doesn’t mean they’re all strong investments. Some lack leverage because they struggle to grow or generate consistent profits, making them unattractive borrowers.
